sections: When the Walt Disney Company built a development in Celebration, Florida, in the 1990s, it was advertised as ‚Äúa place that takes you back to that time of innocence.‚Äù But if that vision was ever even possible, it would ultimately completely unravel.

‚ÄúCelebration was supposed to be a corrective to one of the prevailing anxieties on the eve of the new millennium: that people were more alienated, less connected, less happy,‚Äù wrote Gaby Del Valle in a new piece for

‚ÄúBut Celebration was, at its core, a conventional real estate development masquerading as a utopia. And the minute Disney realized it could get a better return on its investment by selling Celebration for parts, it did.‚Äù
In addition to a recap of

‚Äôs reporting this week, this edition of Lever Weekly features reporting on the widespread use of unpaid labor in prisons, and on the reasons that President Joe Biden should nationalize the oil industry, instead of issuing gentle guidance.
Stuff The Lever Reported This Week:
To Fight Inflation, The Fed Declares War On Workers

‚ÄúDoes the Fed chairman really mistakenly believe that wages are driving inflation? If not, Powell ‚Äî a mega-wealthy private equity mogul and a Republican ‚Äî might have just validated an argument long made by progressives: that a key driver of the central bank‚Äôs interest rate policies is actually to suppress labor power.‚Äù
Powell Lets Wall Street Pay Skyrocket While Targeting Workers‚Äô Wages

‚ÄúThe 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform law mandated the creation of a rule to rein in Wall Street bonuses. The rule is supposed to be developed and implemented by six regulatory agencies, including the Federal Reserve that Powell runs. But as he has sounded the alarm about inflation and wages, Powell has so far has done nothing to help create that rule, even as Wall Street bonuses just hit an all-time record at $45 billion in a single year.‚Äù
The Austerity Push Is A Repeat Of History

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been here before, and we know how it usually goes: A Democratic president loses a midterm election and then is pressured by party strategists and corporate media to dunk on the left and brandish his bipartisan bona fides ‚Äî and that‚Äôs when the triangulation and the austerity comes.‚Äù

‚ÄúFormer Environmental Protection Agency administrator Scott Pruitt resigned in June 2018 amid a cloud of ethics scandals, seemingly too corrupt even for the Trump administration. Now he is attempting to regain a position in the government ‚Äî despite the fact that he has continued to make questionable moves on behalf of the oil and gas industry since leaving his post.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis summer is expected to bring more widespread power outages around the world than any year in recent history. Such blackouts are often deadly, especially during heat waves when people rely on air conditioning or fans to stay cool. Give us five minutes of your time to read this new edition of Cheat Sheet, and we will explain why you might lose power this summer, and what the situation reveals about our energy systems and the climate crisis.‚Äù
U LOVE TO SEE IT: Four-Day Workweeks Gain Traction
‚ÄúA new National Bureau of Economic Research report shows that a four-day workweek has become more prevalent than at any point in the last 50 years.‚Äù

‚ÄúAn affordable company town is still a company town, after all; it may take on the appearance of a community, but it exists for the benefit of the corporation. In many ways, this makes Disney just like any other private housing developer.‚Äù

‚ÄúTexas is one of seven states, all in the South, that force people in prison to work but pay them nothing for almost all jobs. (The others are Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, and South Carolina.)‚Äù
Biden Wrote a Stern Letter to Oil Refiners. His Government Should Take Over the Industry Instead.

‚ÄúVirtually every other major oil producing country on earth has some say over how their natural resources are exploited and refined, making the U.S. something of an outlier in having to go begging to combative CEOs.‚Äù
The Supreme Court Has Had Fox News Brain For a Long Time

‚ÄúOn December 4 ‚Äî the same day the Court issued its first opinion in Bush v. Gore ‚Äî [Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O‚ÄôConnor] absolutely teed off on the Gore campaign at a private party in Washington. ‚ÄòYou just don‚Äôt know what those Gore people have been doing,‚Äù said O‚ÄôConnor, a Republican appointee, whom [author Jeffrey Toobin] describes as ‚Äòlivid‚Äô and speaking ‚Äòwith fervor.‚Äô ‚ÄòThey went into a nursing home and registered people that they shouldn‚Äôt have. It was outrageous.‚Äô‚Äù
Stuff to Watch and Listen To:
WATCH NOW: Biden's Medicare Premium Hike

Watch our new video on the Biden administration‚Äôs recent announcement that it will enact the highest Medicare premium hikes in history just before the midterms. Meanwhile, Biden is moving forward with a plan to further privatize Medicare and funnel the profits to private equity.
LEVER TIME: The Fed Hates You (Also, How To Build A Third Party)
In the new episode of our weekly podcast
, David is joined by economics professor Joshua William Mason and
‚Äôs Julia Rock to discuss how the Federal Reserve is planning to curb inflation‚Ä¶ by lowering workers‚Äô wages.
LEVER LIVE: Is The Senate Gun Deal Good Or Bad? And Is Ethical Consumption Even A Thing?

Watch the replay of this week‚Äôs live show, in which David Sirota answers questions about the Senate‚Äôs bipartisan gun deal, and Lever columnist Kate Aronoff discusses the issue of ethical consumption amid a climate crisis.
